1.text:
Top 10 Famous People Who Didn’t Actually
Exist

12.text:
It seems that every few years, rumors arise
about mysterious athletes in obscure countries

17.text:
whose talents are guaranteed to change the
future of sports.

20.text:
One of the most recent examples concerned
Masal Bugoluv, a supposed 16-year-old soccer

25.text:
prodigy from the small eastern European country
of Moldova.

28.text:
News of the phenom first broke on soccer blogs
and forums, where Bugoluv was described as

33.text:
a surgical striker who already played for
the Moldovan national team.

37.text:
Soon enough, the mainstream soccer media—known
the world over for their tendency to play

40.text:
fast and loose with the facts—had picked
up on the story.

43.text:
The popular website Goal.com posted news about
the player, and in early January of 2009,

48.text:
even the Times of London was on board, listing
Bugoluv as “Moldova’s finest” and linking

53.text:
him with a possible move to the famous English
club Arsenal.

56.text:
But the more the rumors about “Massi”
began to heat up, they more they became suspect.

61.text:
After some background checking and research,
a soccer blogger named Neil McDonnell was

64.text:
able to prove the truth: Masal Bugoluv didn’t
exist.

67.text:
In fact, the whole media whirlwind was all
a hoax allegedly perpetrated by an Irishman

71.text:
who was fed up with the glut of fake information
circulated during soccer’s transfer season.

77.text:
In order to test just how unreliable media
outlets were, he’d decided to invent his

82.text:
With the help of fake Wikipedia articles,
blog posts, and falsified reports from the

86.text:
Associated Press, he created a cult following
for what turned out to be the greatest soccer

94.text:
At some point we’ve probably all looked
at a piece of modern art and thought: “anybody

100.text:
In 1964, Swedish journalist Dacke Axelsson
actually put this claim to the test.

105.text:
In what has come to be a famous hoax, he took
a series of paintings by a chimpanzee named

110.text:
Peter, a ward of the local zoo, and began
circulating them around Sweden as the work

115.text:
of an unknown French artist he called Pierre
Bressau.

118.text:
In order to put art critics to the test, Axelsson
chose a few of Peter’s best paintings and

122.text: set up an exhibition in Gothenburg.

124.text:
Sure enough, the mysterious Mr. Bressau was
hailed by some as a bold new talent.

129.text:
One writer even claimed that the work showed
all the signs of “an artist who performs

133.text: with the delicacy of a ballet dancer.”

135.text:
Surprisingly, once the paintings were revealed
as the work of a primate, none of the art

141.text:
In fact, Rolf Anderberg, the critic who’d
been Bressau’s biggest champion, insisted

145.text:
that Peter’s work was still the best thing
at the exhibition.

148.text:
Of course, not all the critics fell for Axelsson’s
ruse.

151.text:
One writer reportedly remarked that “only
an ape” could be responsible for the paintings.

158.text:
Film fans and critics often rail against so-called
“quote whores”—reviewers who are willing

162.text:
to write a positive notice for any movie as
long as the studios wine and dine them enough—and

167.text:
David Manning of the Ridgefield Press was
seemingly one of the worst.

171.text:
Around 2000, his glowing reviews frequently
appeared on the posters for such universally

175.text:
loathed films as The Animal (“another winner!”)
and Hollow Man (“stupendous!”).

181.text:
Manning would have been a running contender
for America’s worst working film critic,

184.text: save for one key detail: he didn’t exist.

187.text:
As it turned out, a marketing executive at
Sony had invented Manning as a tool for building

191.text:
positive press for films released by the corporation’s
subsidiary Columbia Pictures.

196.text:
Newsweek discovered the deception when a reporter
contacted the Ridgefield Press, a small weekly

200.text:
paper in Connecticut, only to discover that
no one named David Manning had ever worked

206.text:
The incident proved to be a major black eye
for Sony’s marketing division, and a spokesperson

210.text:
for the studio would later claim they were
“horrified” by the whole episode.

214.text:
Not only that, but it also cost them as much
as $1.5 million after two moviegoers in California

219.text:
sued the studio, saying that the phantom film
critic had unfairly lured them into seeing

227.text:
These days, there are plenty of people who
are famous for not really doing anything,

231.text:
so it only seems fitting that someone could
become a celebrity without ever actually existing.

235.text:
Allegra Coleman was a fake starlet invented
by journalist Martha Sherrill.

239.text:
As part of a large-scale media hoax, in 1996
Sherrill wrote an article for Esquire declaring

245.text:
Coleman to be “Hollywood’s Next Dream
Girl.”

248.text:
She even got model Ali Larter, not yet famous,
to pose as the “actress” on the magazine’s

254.text:
The article contained all the usual celebrity
hi jinks, from battles with the paparazzi

257.text:
over supposed nude photos to a rocky relationship
with actor David Schwimmer.

262.text:
Sherrill intended the article to be a satire
of the “puff pieces” that fill so many

266.text:
gossip magazines, but it was also telling
about the way Hollywood works: even after

271.text:
the whole affair was revealed to be a hoax,
publicists and agents were still frantically

275.text:
trying to sign Allegra Coleman to their agencies,
and the whole episode ended up jumpstarting

284.text:
Legendary journalist George Plimpton is famous
for trying out for the Detroit Lions and sparring

288.text:
with Sugar Ray Robinson, but one of his most
memorable stunts was the creation of a phantom

294.text:
In April of 1985, Plimpton engineered one
of the all-time greatest April Fools’ Day

298.text:
hoaxes when he published an article in
Sports Illustrated detailing the arrival of

303.text:
baseball’s next super star, an unknown pitcher
called Hayden “Sidd” Finch.

308.text:
The piece stated that Finch was a mysterious
28-year-old who’d spent time studying at

312.text:
Harvard and searching for inner peace in the
Far East.

314.text:
He’d never played organized baseball before,
but thanks to an unorthodox wind-up that gave

318.text:
him the ability to throw the ball an unbelievable
168 mph, he was considering signing up with

326.text:
Plimpton’s article went on to discuss Finch’s
many eccentricities, which included wearing

330.text:
only one hiking boot when on the mound, playing
the French Horn at a professional level, sleeping

335.text:
on the floor, and speaking in cryptic Zen
koans.

338.text:
The article was accompanied by pictures of
Sidd Finch—played by an unknown high school

342.text:
teacher named Joe Berton—hanging out with
other Mets players like Lenny Dykstra and

347.text:
After a brief uproar of fascination and disbelief—Sports
Illustrated received almost 2000 letters about

352.text:
the story—the magazine announced that Finch
had held a press conference announcing his

357.text:
A week later, they finally came clean about
the hoax.

362.text:
One of the most famous Popes of all time is
the one that modern day scholars believe probably

367.text:
Pope Joan was a figure who was once believed
to have served as Pontiff for a few years

374.text:
Her story first appeared in the 13th century
writings of a Dominican Friar called Jean

379.text:
De Mailly, and for centuries it was a well-known
legend in Europe.

382.text:
The tale came in many forms, but the most
popular version described Joan as pious and

386.text:
brilliant woman who, after disguising herself
as a man, rose quickly through the ranks of

391.text: the Catholic Church and was chosen as Pope.

393.text:
Her reign supposedly came to an end when,
while riding on horseback one day, she suddenly

397.text: fell ill and gave birth to a child.

400.text:
Here the story takes many different turns:
some versions say she died in childbirth,

404.text:
others say natural causes, and others still
say that an angry mob murdered her.

408.text:
While historians have found enough evidence
to reject the idea that Pope Joan ever really

412.text:
existed—some have claimed that the tale
originated in a satirical story about Pope

414.text:
John XI—there’s no denying her legend
played a major part in the religion of the

418.text:
Religious scholars and popular writers like
Boccaccio often made references to her, and

419.text:
there are reports of statues of her being
erected.

420.text:
The legend persisted for several hundred years,
and it took until 1601 before Pope Clement

424.text:
The internet has long been a breeding ground
for hoaxes and alter egos, and lonelygirl15

425.text: is perhaps the most famous example.

427.text:
The name refers to the YouTube handle of a
16-year-old girl named Bree who started posting

431.text: video blogs on the site in 2006.

434.text:
At first, the videos were nothing more than
the online diary of an average high-school

438.text:
student, complete with quirky effects and
complaints about how boring her hometown was.

443.text:
Lonelygirl15 quickly became a hit, and was
eventually the most popular channel on YouTube.

447.text:
But after a few episodes, Bree’s growing
fan base began to be suspicious over whether

452.text:
A number of websites and forums soon sprang
up, and amateur detectives began poring over

457.text: the videos looking for clues and inconsistencies.

459.text:
It didn’t take long before it was discovered
that “Bree” was in fact Jessica Rose,

465.text:
a 19-year-old L.A.-based actress, and that
her YouTube account was actually a carefully

468.text:
scripted media hoax designed to eventually
expand into a full-fledged television show.

473.text:
The whole episode briefly made lonelygirl15
a cultural phenomenon, and the show continued

478.text:
for a further two years, eventually taking
on a quasi-sci-fi plot that featured a sweeping

485.text:
The character of “Bree,” once considered
by many to be a real teenager, was killed

493.text:
Comedian Andy Kaufman was famous for playing
with audience expectations by mixing performance

497.text:
art and mysterious alter egos into his stand
up.

500.text:
One of his most famous creations was Tony
Clifton, a washed-up, vulgar, and often-drunk

505.text:
lounge singer who served as the opening act
for Kaufman’s comedy gigs.

509.text:
With his terrible singing voice, confrontational
attitude, and tendency to forget his lyrics,

514.text:
Clifton summed up every stereotype of the
aging Vegas entertainer, and he soon became

520.text:
After it surfaced that Clifton was actually
being portrayed by Kaufman in costume and

525.text:
makeup—something both men denied—Kaufman
enlisted both his brother and his friend Bob

529.text:
Zmuda to portray the character on stage in
order to further the illusion that he and

535.text:
Tony Clifton was soon making appearances on
everything from David Letterman’s late night

539.text:
show to Dinah Shore’s talk show, where he
was famously thrown out of the studio for

543.text: dumping a plate of eggs on the host’s head.

545.text:
He was even slated to appear as a special
guest on the sitcom Taxi, but was kicked off

551.text:
Kaufman died in 1984 without ever revealing
the truth about the character, and even today

556.text:
it’s not widely known how many times he
actually appeared as Clifton, or how many

559.text: times an accomplice stepped into the role.

562.text:
The gruff lounge singer has continued to make
appearances since Kaufman’s death, which

565.text:
has only furthered the illusion that Tony
Clifton is actually a real person.

572.text:
Director Alan Smithee has enjoyed a long and
varied career, which has seen him make everything

576.text:
from feature films to television pilots, cartoons,
and music videos.

580.text:
He’d be one of Hollywood’s most prolific
filmmakers if not for one key fact: he doesn’t

586.text:
Since 1968, directors who wish to have their
name removed from the credits of their films

590.text:
have used the name “Alan Smithee” as a
pseudonym.

593.text:
Alan Smithee was first employed by Don Siegel
on the film Death of a Gunfighter, and it’s

597.text:
since been used whenever a director feels
that their creative control over a film project

601.text:
has been compromised to the extent that the
final product is no longer their work.

606.text:
With this in mind, Alan Smithee now has 73
directorial credits on the website Internet

611.text:
Movie Database, including such lamentable
productions as Hellraiser: Bloodline and Solar

616.text:
Crisis, along with TV projects including episodes
of The Cosby Show and MacGyver.

622.text:
Mainstream directors like Michael Mann and
Paul Verhoeven have also used the credit in

623.text:
instances where movies like Heat or Showgirls
are significantly edited for exhibition on

627.text:
The Director’s Guild of America officially
abandoned Alan Smithee in the late nineties,

630.text:
after the release of a film called An Alan
Smithee Film: Burn Hollywood Burn drew unwanted

637.text:
Since then, unhappy filmmakers have chosen
their own pseudonyms, but others continue

640.text: to use Alan Smithee as a sort of tribute.

643.text:
In fact, since 2000, the phantom director
has racked up a further 18 film credits.

651.text:
There might be more well known entries on
this list, but none of them had the same influence

654.text:
on world politics, religion, or exploration
as Prester John, a mythical king who was once

659.text:
believed to have presided over a Christian
empire in Asia.

662.text:
His legend dates back to the 12th century,
when it arose as an amalgam of adventure stories,

667.text:
true histories of Christian missionaries,
and the exploits of Alexander the Great.

671.text:
Prester John and his kingdom became a true
sensation in 1165, when a letter supposedly

675.text: written by him began circulating around Europe.

679.text:
According to these fantastical sources, Prester
John was a direct descendant of one of the

685.text:
His kingdom, which was suspected to be in
India or the Middle East, was seen by the

688.text:
Europeans of the time as a shining light of
civilization in a region that was viewed as

695.text:
Prester John himself was believed to be a
kind and wise man who ruled over an empire

699.text:
of great wealth, and his kingdom was often
said to include such wonders as the Fountain

703.text: of Youth and even the Garden of Eden.

705.text:
Despite little evidence of his existence,
the legend of Prester John persisted for several

709.text:
hundred years, and for a time he was even
linked with the Mongol warlord Genghis Khan.

714.text:
It would take until the 1600s before academics
and travelers were able to prove that Prester

718.text:
John was nothing but a myth, but in the interim
the legendary king had managed to affect everything

724.text:
Not only had missionaries stepped up their
efforts in Asia and Africa in the hope of

728.text:
discovering Prester John’s kingdom, but
explorers like Magellan were encouraged to

732.text:
seek out new lands in the hope that they might
one day stumble upon the mythical ruler.
